metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: jQuery - Add Elements
With jQuery, it is easy to add new elements/content.
content.html: With jQuery, it is easy to add new elements/content.

content.text: Add New HTML Content
We will look at four jQuery methods that are used to add new content:
content.html: We will look at four jQuery methods that are used to add new content:

content.text: jQuery append() Method
The jQuery append() method inserts content AT THE END of the selected HTML elements.
content.html: The jQuery append() method inserts content AT THE END of the selected HTML elements.

content.code_html: $("p").append("Some appended text.");

content.text: jQuery prepend() Method
The jQuery prepend() method inserts content AT THE BEGINNING of the selected HTML elements.
content.html: The jQuery prepend() method inserts content AT THE BEGINNING of the selected HTML elements.

content.code_html: $("p").prepend("Some prepended text.");

content.text: Add Several New Elements With append() and prepend()
In both examples above, we have only inserted some text/HTML at the beginning/end of the selected HTML elements.
content.html: In both examples above, we have only inserted some text/HTML at the beginning/end of the selected HTML elements.

content.text: However, both the append() and prepend() methods can take an infinite number of new elements as parameters. The new elements can be generated with text/HTML (like we have done in the examples above), with jQuery, or with JavaScript code and DOM elements.
content.html: However, both the append() and prepend() methods can take an infinite number of new elements as parameters. The new elements can be generated with text/HTML (like we have done in the examples above), with jQuery, or with JavaScript code and DOM elements.

content.text: In the following example, we create several new elements. The elements are created with text/HTML, jQuery, and JavaScript/DOM. Then we append the new elements to the text with the append() method (this would have worked for prepend() too) :
content.html: In the following example, we create several new elements. The elements are created with text/HTML, jQuery, and JavaScript/DOM. Then we append the new elements to the text with the append() method (this would have worked for prepend() too) :

content.code_html:
function appendText() {
  var txt1 = "<p>Text.</p>";               // Create element with HTML 
  var txt2 = $("<p></p>").text("Text.");   // Create with jQuery
   var txt3 = document.createElement("p");  // Create with DOM
   txt3.innerHTML = "Text.";
  $("body").append(txt1, txt2, txt3);      // Append the new elements
}

content.text: jQuery after() and before() Methods
The jQuery after() method inserts content AFTER the selected HTML elements.
content.html: The jQuery after() method inserts content AFTER the selected HTML elements.

content.text: The jQuery before() method inserts content BEFORE the selected HTML elements.
content.html: The jQuery before() method inserts content BEFORE the selected HTML elements.

content.code_html:
$("img").after("Some text after");

$("img").before("Some text before");

content.text: Add Several New Elements With after() and before()

Also, both the after() and before() methods can take an infinite number of new elements as parameters. The new elements can be generated with text/HTML (like we have done in the example above), with jQuery, or with JavaScript code and DOM elements.
content.html: Also, both the after() and before() methods can take an infinite number of new elements as parameters. The new elements can be generated with text/HTML (like we have done in the example above), with jQuery, or with JavaScript code and DOM elements.

content.text: In the following example, we create several new elements. The elements are created with text/HTML, jQuery, and JavaScript/DOM. Then we insert the new elements to the text with the after() method (this would have worked for before() too) :
content.html: In the following example, we create several new elements. The elements are created with text/HTML, jQuery, and JavaScript/DOM. Then we insert the new elements to the text with the after() method (this would have worked for before() too) :

content.code_html:
function afterText() {
  var txt1 = "<b>I </b>";                    // Create element with HTML 
  var txt2 = $("<i></i>").text("love ");     // Create with jQuery
   var txt3 = document.createElement("b");    // Create with DOM
   txt3.innerHTML = "jQuery!";
  $("img").after(txt1, txt2, txt3);          // Insert new elements after <img>
 }

content.text: jQuery Exercises
Test Yourself With Exercises
Exercise:

Use a jQuery method to insert the text "YES!" at the end of a

element.
content.html: Use a jQuery method to insert the text "YES!" at the end of a <p> element.

content.text: Start the Exercise
jQuery HTML Reference
For a complete overview of all jQuery HTML methods, please go to our jQuery HTML/CSS Reference .
content.html: For a complete overview of all jQuery HTML methods, please go to our jQuery HTML/CSS Reference.
